object.data:
Fig 1

 

Fig 1
The respiratory system (also respiratory apparatus, ventilatory system) is a biological system consisting of specific organs (shown in fig 1) and structures used for gas exchanges.

The upper tract includes the nose, nasal cavities, sinuses, pharynx and the part of the larynx above the vocal folds. The lower tract includes the lower part of the larynx, the trachea, bronchi, bronchioles and the alveoli.

• Your right lung is divided into three LOBES, or sections. Each lobe is like a balloon filled with sponge-like tissue. Air moves in and out through one openingâ€”a branch of the bronchial tube.
  • Your left lung is divided into two LOBES.
  • The PLEURA are the two membranes, actually, one continuous one folded on itself, that surround each lobe of the lungs and separate your lungs from your chest wall.
  • The smallest branches of the bronchial tubes are called BRONCHIOLES, at the end of which are the air sacs or alveoli.
  • ALVEOLI are the very small air sacs where the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide takes place.
  • CAPILLARIES are blood vessels in the walls of the alveoli. Blood passes through the capillaries, entering through your PULMONARY ARTERY and leaving via your PULMONARY VEIN. While in the capillaries, blood gives off carbon dioxide through the capillary wall into the alveoli and takes up oxygen from air in the alveoli.

Smoking destroys the alveoli, in the lungs that allow oxygen exchange. When you smoke, you are damaging some of those air sacs. Alveoli don't grow back, so when you destroy them, you have permanently destroyed part of your lungs. When enough alveoli are destroyed, the disease emphysema develops. Emphysema causes severe shortness of breath and can lead to death.

Alveoli have:

  • Large surface area - many alveoli are present in the lungs with a shape that further increases surface area.
  • Thin walls - alveolar walls are one cell thick providing gases with a short diffusion distance.
  • Moist walls - gases dissolve in the moisture helping them to pass across the gas exchange surface.
  • Permeable walls - allow gases to pass through.

There are two types of cells in an alveolus. Type I cells have long cytoplasmic extensions that cover more than 95% of the alveolar surface.The cytoplasmcontains pinocytotic vesicles whichmay play a role in the removal of small particulate contaminants from the outer surface. In addition to desmosomes (is a cell structure specialized for cell-to-cell adhesion), all type I alveolar cells have occluding junctions that prevent the leakage of tissue fluid into the alveolar air space. Type II cells in the alveolar wall contain secretory organelles known as lamellar bodies that fuse with the cell membranes and secrete pulmonary surfactant. This surfactant is a film of fatty substances, a group of phospholipids that reduce alveolar surface tension. The phospholipids are stored in the lamellar bodies. Without this coating, the alveoli would collapse.

Contents

...

Help

eLearning Module Structure

Learning Module is a fundamental building block of the Course hierarchy representing the set of author-structured Slides. During the learning process the learner is led from one Slide to another sequentially, which is default behavior.
Slide (Interactive page) is the main building block of Learning Module. Slides are used by the author to place learning material, tests, and exercises. The order of Slide correlation is predefined by the author.

Navigation

eLearning Module navigation controls (the list may vary depending on author's design):

  • "Prev" and "Next" buttons enable to jump on previous and next slide correspondingly; 
  • "Replay" button enable to start current slide once again from the beginning (it may be useful, for example, to repeat animation on slide etc.);
  • "Contents" tab or button with popup window displays the list of all slides and enables transition to any slide in the Module (if no restrictions were applied by author);
  • Navigation drop-down menu displays the list of all slides and enables transition to any slide in the Module (if no restrictions were applied by author);
  • "Sound On/Off" button toggles narration (if narration exists in the Module);
  • "Close Module" button closes Module window.

Please note that some controls may become disabled while navigating. Usually it means that:

  • not all objects of current slide are displayed yet (depending on rules defined by author);
  • not all activities required from learner on current slide are finished (for example, navigation controls may be disabled until question is answered etc.);
  • navigation action is just impossible (for example, there's no slides previous to first one).

Calculator

0

Settings

Module state
. .

About

This eLearning Module was developed using CourseLabÂ® eLearning Content Editor. Depending on purpose this Module can be used in any AICC- or SCORM-compatible Learning Management System, on CD etc.

Hardware/Software requirements

This eLearning Module can be played on any PC that meets requirements below:

  • Operating System - MicrosoftÂ® Windows 98, Me, NT, 2000, XP (limited support of Windows 95) or Linux;
  • Internet Browser - MicrosoftÂ® Internet Explorer 5.0 (Internet Explorer 5.5 or higher recommended), Mozilla FireFox 1.0 or higher, NetscapeÂ® 7.2 or higher;
  • JavaScript enabled;
  • XML support enabled (MicrosoftÂ® XML Parser 3.0 or higher recommended for Internet Explorer).

Additional requirements may be applied depending on media types used by Module author.

param.msg: You cannot jump to this slide until you visit previous slides
You cannot jump to this slide until you visit previous slides

param.tabtext:
eLearning Module Structure

Learning Module is a fundamental building block of the Course hierarchy representing the set of author-structured Slides. During the learning process the learner is led from one Slide to another sequentially, which is default behavior.
Slide (Interactive page) is the main building block of Learning Module. Slides are used by the author to place learning material, tests, and exercises. The order of Slide correlation is predefined by the author.

Navigation

eLearning Module navigation controls (the list may vary depending on author's design):

  • "Prev" and "Next" buttons enable to jump on previous and next slide correspondingly; 
  • "Replay" button enable to start current slide once again from the beginning (it may be useful, for example, to repeat animation on slide etc.);
  • "Contents" tab or button with popup window displays the list of all slides and enables transition to any slide in the Module (if no restrictions were applied by author);
  • Navigation drop-down menu displays the list of all slides and enables transition to any slide in the Module (if no restrictions were applied by author);
  • "Sound On/Off" button toggles narration (if narration exists in the Module);
  • "Close Module" button closes Module window.

Please note that some controls may become disabled while navigating. Usually it means that:

  • not all objects of current slide are displayed yet (depending on rules defined by author);
  • not all activities required from learner on current slide are finished (for example, navigation controls may be disabled until question is answered etc.);
  • navigation action is just impossible (for example, there's no slides previous to first one).

This eLearning Module was developed using CourseLabÂ® eLearning Content Editor. Depending on purpose this Module can be used in any AICC- or SCORM-compatible Learning Management System, on CD etc.

Hardware/Software requirements

This eLearning Module can be played on any PC that meets requirements below:

  • Operating System - MicrosoftÂ® Windows 98, Me, NT, 2000, XP (limited support of Windows 95) or Linux;
  • Internet Browser - MicrosoftÂ® Internet Explorer 5.0 (Internet Explorer 5.5 or higher recommended), Mozilla FireFox 1.0 or higher, NetscapeÂ® 7.2 or higher;
  • JavaScript enabled;
  • XML support enabled (MicrosoftÂ® XML Parser 3.0 or higher recommended for Internet Explorer).

Additional requirements may be applied depending on media types used by Module author.

param.textbox_text: The upper tract includes the nose, nasal cavities, sinuses, pharynx and the part of the larynx above the vocal folds. The lower tract includes the lower part of the larynx, the trachea, bronchi, bronchioles and the alveoli.

  • Moist walls - gases dissolve in the moisture helping them to pass across the gas exchange surface.

item.q_variant: Causes sever shortness of breath and can lead to death.
Is a disease caused by the destruction of blood vessels that grows back with medication and time.
Is a diseases caused by the destruction of alveoli which can grow back with medication and time.
Is a disease that is caused by the destruction of alveoli that dosen't grow back.
